ResponsesInList.Title: Adding Degree Program & Semesters
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm a new user here and gonna start using moodle for my first ever project which includes a learning management system as mostly universities have. I'm sure that there will be any plugin etc used for adding degree programs & semester format in moodle as most of the universities of the world using moodle also have similar format. Any guidance/help in this regard please?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Degree Program & Semesters
ResponsesInList.Text: Categories are just that and can be used to organise your courses in any way you choose - including sub-categories to whatever level you need. So one suggestion would be to have your degree programs as a top level category, semesters as a sub-category in each one and then the courses themselves inside the semesters. It doesn't need a plugin, just organise your categories and courses the way you want them (I find a paper and pencil exercise or card decks a good place to start.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Hidden sections -- view only, not control hide/show
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 3.0 A colleague would like to use a hidden section in a course for quality assurance. In the hidden section, he would place answer keys, model answers, model feedback, etc., for education inspectors to access. I have created a custom inspector role, but the closest capability I found is the moodle/course:sectionvisibility option. I haven't got it to work yet for the Inspector role (do I need to purge caches?), but I realize it is not exactly what I want, that is, I want the capability to view hidden sections , but the capability to control section visibility. Is this possible?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hidden sections -- view only, not control hide/show
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes -- absolutely possible. Sounds like you want your Inspector to have the ability to see the hidden sections of a course ( moodle/course:viewhiddensections ), but not control it's visibility ( moodle/course:sectionvisibility) - definitely two separate permissions. Another consideration -- add a folder to your course that has all the answer keys in it -- and either hide the folder (so students don't see it), group the folder to a specific group (such as a Teacher's Only group), or remove the students role's capability to 'view' this specific Folder (at the activity level).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Maybe wrong forum? Meta course help please
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Clare, The documentation does specify two ways of doing this: 1. Create individual courses (not metacourse), then create one metacourse. This would be used, for example, when getting students from different sections (example PSYCHOLOGY 101 Sections 1 to 20) into a departmental site (PSYCHOLOGY Department site); OR 2. In scenario two of your link, create one individual course (not metacourse), then create multiple metacourses. This would be used, for example, when all five courses are intended to have exactly the same students. In both cases, you can see students being enrolled normally into standard courses and then the entire student list of a course being added to the Metacourse. The individual course/s must be created FIRST, as the course name is what you would use in the metacourse to enroll the users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Courses hidden when course format deleted
ResponsesInList.Text: This information might be useful when deciding to delete a course format. When upgrading to Moodle 4.1.6 from 3.11.6 we decided not to use the format Collapsed Topics anymore. The Topics course format now has the functionality we wanted when we installed Collapsed Topics. When just disabling CT, the courses using the format still used I. So, following directions found regarding this we decided to uninstall it completely, since Topics is the default course format for courses to use. It worked well in our test server ; courses using CT "fell back" to Topics instead. But, when uninstalling Collapse Topics from our production server we also noted that all courses having used Collapsed Topics got hidden from students. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Names - Good Practice Examples
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Anna, Pragmatically I believe that you should not restrict yourself but use whatever naming you require that makes sense to the user. I have organised a short name prefix in the past to help ensure that they were unique across the organisation, such as 'EN_' for English Department, 'IT_' for IT Department etc.  The course creator would then have a free reign on the rest. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Names - Good Practice Examples
ResponsesInList.Text: Good question - it seems so simple doesn't it to setup course names. However, down the road the choice of naming structure can present problems for both users, teachers and administrators. Here's my view... 1. If you were providing courses in the physical world then these would probably be listed in a 'catalogue' of some kind. The names in the catalogue should be meaningful and attractive to the potential 'users' - they are acting as 'advertising' and 'marketing' devices. So, in a Moodle space the smae should apply. 2. Long Moodle names are thoese that the potential users will see to 'attract' them...they should therefore convey enough menaing to draw people to the right course 3. Short names are used in palces ONCE A USER IS IN A COURSE - these don't have to be so comprehensive but should convey enough meaning for users, teachers and administrators to underdstand the source or target of any e-mail, post, log messages, reports etc. A tip - if you want to be precise about course identification consider using the Course ID Number field in course settings - this is an internal reference only, it could link to the course providers own catalogue of courses for complete clarity. Hope this helps. Graham

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Names - Good Practice Examples
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings! I am at a small, liberal arts university in the USA using Moodle 1.9.9 with around 650 courses each Fall and Spring semesters. Our organization and approach to the naming of course sites is: categories for each academic year - e.g. 2010 - 2011 - and then subcategories for each semester - e.g. Spring 2011 Full Name is the name of the course that the student/teacher will see and the teacher can change this if they would like. This is also what shows in the "breadcrumb trail" - did a little tweak to accomplish that Both the Short Name and Course ID Number are identical and are using the same naming/numbering listed elsewhere across the university with a semester and year tag added. The Short Name and Course ID Number cannot be changed by the teacher. For example: Full name = Greek Civilization Short name = CLA0731401-spring-11 Course ID Number = CLA0731401-spring-11 The reason for tweaking the "breadcrumb trail" to show the full name of the course is because that is typically how students and professors refer to their classes. Enjoy!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to use same course in Multiple categories (not duplicate or reuse)
ResponsesInList.Text: In theory, it could be achieved with some custom code. If there is a file 'externservercourse.php' in the 'course' directory on the Moodle server , which contains the function 'extern_server_course', then that can be used to redirect the user to a different URL . The way it would be set up is the 'real' course is placed in one category, then empty courses are placed in the other categories. When a user visits one of the empty courses, then they are immediately redirected to the 'real' course. Unfortunately, when arriving at the 'real' course, it is listed in its actual category (not the category where you started), but it is a way of providing a sort of shortcut from a course in one place in the category tree, to another. It also requires a bit of coding, if you want a proper interface for setting up the links (rather than just hard-coding a bunch of course ids into the 'externservercourse.php' script).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Collapsed Topics - Open or Closed when returning to a page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard, If you look in: Home-> Site administration -> Plugins -> Course formats -> Collapsed Topics - you will find a setting 'defaulttogglepersistence' to turn of the functionality that remembers the state of the toggles. ResponsesInList.Title: Collapsed Topics release candidate version V500.0.1 for Moodle 5.0 released
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I've released the release candidate version of the Collapsed Topics course format for Moodle 5.0 as follows: Release 500.0.1 for Moodle 5.0 version 2025041400.00 (Build: 20250414) and above within the MOODLE_500_STABLE branch: https://moodle.org/plugins/format_topcoll/500.0.1/35794 https://github.com/gjbarnard/moodle-format_topcoll/releases/tag/V500.0.1 with: First Moodle 5.0 version. Update section highlight in line with core changes. Plus from the V405.1.0: Fix 'ARIA attribute for accessibility : aria-labelledby' - #160. Fix keyboard control of toggles in terms of focussing only on a the actual element that does the toggling. Fix 'Space key input not registered with the system Inplace editable in sections titles' - #161. Fix 'defaulttogglepersistence' not working. Improve single section page logic, especially when returning to course from creating a module. Important: Because of 'Subsection support' which has been incredibly difficult to support to the extent that I've had to wave a 'white flag' and remove the 'numsections' setting.  The course format API has been broken apart into so many interconnected small pieces (each tending to have separate PHP, JS and Mustache files), https://moodledev.io/docs/4.5/apis/plugintypes/format#format-output-classes-and-templates and https://moodledev.io/docs/4.5/apis/plugintypes/format#the-course-editor-structure , that it is difficult at times to understand and keep in working memory what is going on and where a given element of functionality is implemented to the extent where it can be overridden and changed.  Thus the format will now operate as 'Topics' does in terms of number of sections management.  Collapsed Topics was only ever designed to operate on sections and as such sees sub-sections as different entities not related to the number of sections in a course.  Collapsed Topics will now not allow you to have as many 'Sub sections' as you want - as was in V405.0.2 - due to increased chance of course restore failure, see: MDL-84874 .  Additional tracker issues of interest for this are: MDL-84038 and MDL-84291 . Because of the removal of 'numsections', this has an impact on backup and restore, which I've tested.  However with such a change brings risk and a greater chance of error, thus I cannot stress enough that you MUST test and be sure that the format works as expected before it goes anywhere near a production server .  I found with the Grid format that once 'numsections' was removed that it was tricky to go back, and therefore it would be unlikely even with the flexibility I like of being able to set the number of sections both as a course setting and add / remove in the course itself. I have refactored the whole toggle state preference JavaScript such that it no longer uses YUI.  This I hope will help to keep the format going for many years to come as older technologies are removed from core. Note: Always install on a test server to confirm that the format does what you want it to do before updating or installing on a production server!  And as this release could contain bugs and so I strongly recommend that you check on a test server first!  Not sure how to set one up?  Then look at the 'Installer packages' on https://download.moodle.org/releases/latest/ . Ensure that you have multiple backups of all data before using.  Please report any issues. i.e. 'bugs' with this release ONLY here.  Before doing so please read 'Reporting issues' on the 'Information' tab on the course format 'Settings' under 'Site administration' -> 'Plugins' -> 'Course formats' -> 'Collapsed Topics'. If you find this post useful, then please mark it so. Thank you, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: course context id
ResponsesInList.Text: Does a course have a unique contextid? if so is it easy locate? help would be apprecaited

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: course context id
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes. There is a unique context for each course, activity, block, course category and user. You can find them in the mdl_context table. There, the contextlevel tells you what type of context it is. So, for example, 50 = course and 70 = activity. (The full list of types is defined at the top of lib/accesslib.php.) Then, depending on the type of context, the instanceid column links to the appropriate database table. So, if contextlevel = 50, then instanceid matches an id from the mdl_course table. And for contextlevel = 70, instanceid refers to mdl_course_modules.id.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grid format install removed number of sections drop down in course format

Purge all caches. Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recalculating Course Completion

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gif animation file in the grid format didn"t show the animation
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, a quick test on Moodle 2.6.1 and my latest unreleased development version 2014011400 shows that I can replicate the problem.  However, the format uses the PHP GD library to resize the uploaded images which currently does not support reading of animated Gif's - http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.imagecreatefromgif.php .  There is a link to another library - http://www.gdenhancer.com/ - which claims to support them.  However it is for PHP 5.4 and only M2.7 is proposed to have PHP 5.4 as a minimum requirement.  Thus cannot be the solution in M2.5 or M2.6.  Additionally I don't know at this moment in time how difficult it would be to use the library or indeed might make the installation process difficult. Therefore at this moment in time, there is nothing I can do to solve the problem.  Sorry. Cheers, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gif animation file in the grid format didn"t show the animation
ResponsesInList.Text: Now that Moodle 2.7 has been released and stabilized, how do things look for animated gif support? I've look a bit into it, and there seems to be 2 potential workarounds: 1. Imagemagick instead of GD, supports animated gifs (at least according to wikipedia), but is a seperate php extension to be installed. 2. Offer direct uploads without processing the files through GD. Perhaps an option could be added to the "Set the image resize method" dropdown for "None" or "No scaling". Hope you consider these possibilities. Cheers, John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gif animation file in the grid format didn"t show the animation
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear John, Thank you for the information.  With: I do not want to add an install dependency that is outside of the standard Moodle installation and checking.  It will only annoy people and cause lots of 'why is this not working' type questions.  Pragmatically, people do not read instructions, they just want to install the files, click on next without reading the text until it finishes and then expect it to work. Nice idea, but again, this I believe will cause confusion as it is logically intermixing two different functionalities.  So, when the image does not react to the size change then I'll get questions like 'why is the image not resizing when I change the size of the box?'. Ok, I do now see the possibility that when uploading that gif images are left unprocessed and scaled using CSS .  The code as it stands was designed to be as optimal as possible.  However, if a compromise that the full size of the file is downloaded, then it is conceivable that it would work behind the scenes without user interaction.  This will take time to figure out and I don't have time at the moment.  But I'll keep it in the back of my mind for sometime in the future. Cheers, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Text: We've been using Collapsed Topics since converting to Moodle 2+ in January and really have had good success. However, the change for 2.3 introduced an element that we are not very keen on, the massive orange wrench icon dominating the top of the page, causing us to have to scroll down a lot more and making it harder to keep a consistent look and feel across courses. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Turn off Changing Look in Collapsed Topics Format
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Bryan, The spanner ('wrench') icon disappears when the course is not in editing mode.  If you wish to reduce it's size you can edit the inline css in 'format.php' for 'tc_logo_spanner.png'.  It was introduced to provide the functionality of easy customisation that a lot of users were asking for without having to edit code.  The defaults are maintained in the 'config.php' file in the format and the administrator can reset all CT courses to use them with the spanner icon. In the Moodle 2.3 version if you wish to remove the functionality, edit 'renderer.php' and remove: // Collapsed Topics settings. echo $this->settings($course); around lines 351/352.  Then the defaults will be used unless the spanner has been used previously to set course specific settings, in which case you need to edit the rows in 'format_topcoll_settings' in the database or put the spanner back temporarily and do a reset as administrator as mentioned above. The spanner will disapear in Moodle 2.4 when planned custom course settings are added to core and I can move the code in that direction. Regards, Gareth Developer of Collapsed Topics

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course - created by
ResponsesInList.Text: This information is not stored directly in Moodle - you may be able to retrieve it from the logs. You haven't mentioned a Moodle version number, so I will assume you are using Moodle 2.9. The log event you are looking for is \core\event\course_created ( https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Event_2#Existing_events ). You will need to create an instance of \core\log\ sql _reader ( https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Migrating_log_access_in_reports ) and then use that to do a search for the relevant event. The 'userid' for that event will be the user who created the course.

Now I am trying to link our testing software (Examplify) to Moodle but it is getting confused because it can't recognize groups and only the class.  While that shouldn't be an issue it does become one on the testing side as anything posted to a course is available to any in that course and I can't filter it to a specific group. Have been thinking of setting up, what I would call is a master course, so that anything we want the students to see would be there and would only require one spot to be updated if anything changes.  Then I would set-up another "course" specific to that group of students. How do I link them so they don't see the two courses and can the gradebook in the master course pick up marks from the sub-course? Or does anyone have any suggestions of a better set-up?  I don't want to get into just duplicating the course over and over as I feel that would be an issue pertaining to consistency of materials from one to the next.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to notify site users of new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Dear All; I have a Moodle site. There are courses added to the site. I would like to notify the users of the site each time a course has been added so they could come and enroll in the course. Preferably this notification could be turned off by the user. Is there a way to do this? any core functionality? any plugin? If not, how could I develop such module? Regards; Omid

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to notify site users of new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Omid, As far as I am aware, registered users are not automatically notified of new courses, you can however use news block and send user notifications of new courses, that though will put load on your email server for all registered users will get notifications. Alternatively and recommended way is to  make use of social network like FaceBook, Twitter or Google+, your followers will get notifications.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to notify site users of new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Usman; Thank you. You mean I send the notification manually with the news block? I was looking for some kind of automatic notification of any new course created. Regards; Omid

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to notify site users of new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Omid, I am afraid there is no automatic notification of new course uploads, even news has to be manually typed, there is no automatic news feed upon new course upload , where moodle internal notifications will be limited to registered users only, a social network will be open to public and better for your site SEO. how much of work is required to post your new courses to post on a social network? less than a minute.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to notify site users of new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: As Usman says, there isn't - as far as I am aware - an existing feature that does this. However, you could ask in the General developer forum about using Moodle's events system to trigger an email to users. There are other systems within Moodle that trigger notifications (e.g. a user gets notified when a grader marks their assignment), so you could a) find the relevant trigger event when a course is created and b) find how that can be used to send a notification to users - You would probably use the Moodle notification system ratehr than simply an email, because that already has the relevant systems for sending that to both Moodle internal messaging and to emails. Alternatively you could advertise for a developer to do this for you. I think the tools are all there within Moodle, so it's 'just' a case of putting them together in the right ways - that said, the 'just' here would be outside my immediate experience and expertise, so I may be wrong about the complexity of achieving this!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bookmarks (yes once again)
ResponsesInList.Text: Jan-I've been giving this bookmark idea more thought myself. I like the bookmarklet tools that you and Tony developed, and your module in particular I know I will use in at least some of my courses, probably pretty much as is. However, I feel that so far none of the solutions presented allow for anything more than passive consumption of the content of the pages that include the bookmarks. It would be nice, for example, if the bookmarklet tool could be used to insert bookmarks into a glossary, and put into specific categories within that glossary, just as Tony's tool allows one to add bookmarks to a specific topic in a course. The advantage of this is that it could allow for a variety of things to be done. Teachers could allow students to add bookmarks to the glossary and to add them to the various categories, thereby creating a repository of bookmarks in various categories related to the course subject matter. This is more logical for learning purposes than each student having their own personal bookmarks they can share with the class. Their personal contributions could still be noted if the format of the glossary were to show the contributor. Secondly, collecting them in a glossary, and enabling comments on the glossary item, would provide an opportunity for students to reflect more on what they read on the linked pages-it could even be an assignment that students post comments and this would ensure that they were reading what they were supposed to be reading.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Duplicate course

Now I create one csv file, upload it to the course upload feature, and moodle does it all for me.  It is a truly beautiful thing - best feature to come out since I started!

ResponsesInList.Title: Course category only visible for selected users
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Moodlers! I have the following situation: Normally all Course Categories are visible for the students. But now i want to create a special course category which should be only visible for selected users or in another way: users i give access to. How can i do this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course category only visible for selected users
ResponsesInList.Text: On the special category revoke (i.e. prevent) the view capability for the authenticated user role (which *everyone* normally holds) You'll then need to have a role defined that you can assign to the specific users that gives them back the view capability. Students aren't typically in the student role outside of a course context (where they are *enrolled*) so most of the general capabilities are set via the Authenticated User role.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course category only visible for selected users
ResponsesInList.Text: So you need to go to /course/management.php and into the relevant category and assign the role there. However you need to make sure on your Role definition you have set it so that it can be assigned to category contexts.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: change course start date for all courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Change the start date for a chosen course 'example' to the date you want. Check the the table by doing a select id,shortname,startdate from mdl_course where shortname = 'example'; You should now see the startdate for this course .. like 1187560800. You can now run update mdl_course set startdate=1187560800 where id>1000000; Use a where condition to only update courses with id>xxx . The number used above is so that the query won't do much by accident. Look at the ids of the first courses - you might want to skip a few of them. (the first one is the course used for the front page - change the where to where id>1 to only skip the front page course.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Project Course Format
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, The Project course format displays the course as a collection of "phases" and "topics" made of of modules. In fact, this is very similar to the "weeks" and "topics" format, in that each "phase" is actually a "topic" with additional information regarding the start and end dates of the phase. The project format allows to mix phases and topics. A Gantt chart is automatically included in the top area (section 0) of the course. It represents a 'bar' for each phase and a milestone for each assignemt activity that is defined as part of a phase. By mousing over the milestones the teacher gets a list of students who have competed the assignements and who got feedback already. It would be quite easy to add events from the calendar to the Gannt chart. The motivation to develop such a course format is that we have been using a homemade project manager based on postnuke in the past 2 years ( http://teamframes.epfl.ch ). As we are now moving towards using Moodle as our basic elearning toolkit, we wanted to continue supporting teachers who do project-based teaching. The implementation is very preliminary but does the essential. I developed it with 1.5 and then had to adapt some code to have it run under 1.4. It relies on a modified version of JpGraph that allows mouseovers and upon overlib for the popups. Open questions which I have not addressed yet are how to backup such a course including the information about phases. How to allow one member of a group to submit something that 'counts' for all members. How to allow multifile submissions to assignement. How to enable file sharing among the group members. etc. etc. If you are interested in having a look, testing is available at:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Format

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to override course/modeedit.php file in custom theme
ResponsesInList.Text: If you're looking to change the styling of the page, then you can target it using the id tag of the 'body' element of the page (that will allow you to make styling changes to only that page). If the "something" you want to change is not related to the CSS of the page, then you probably can't change it using a theme (and depending on what that "something" is, there's a good chance you cannot change it without making changes directly to the core code).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to override course/modeedit.php file in custom theme
ResponsesInList.Text: If you're looking to add some new settings to the activity settings, you can add some functions in your theme's (or any plugin's) lib.php file to handle that, without changing core code (theme_yourtheme_coursemodule_standard_elements, theme_yourtheme_coursemodule_definition_after_data, theme_yourtheme_coursemodule_edit_post_actions). These functions handle how your data is displayed as a form, and how to handle the data if it is updated. I use it just to display some extra external data about assignments. You can see my use of it here: https://github.com/ltu-solent/moodle-local_solsits/blob/ca897be9687cd05ea72ada28bc64b38cee072fe5/lib.php#L36

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Categories id number
ResponsesInList.Text: You can now do this in Moodle 2.3. You'll see the "Category ID number" field in the interface when you go to edit a category. However, this custom category "id number" is not yet used in some of the new features that use the category "id", such as the external database enrollment plugin that can create courses in a pre-existing category. The term "category id" refers to the id inside the Moodle database for each category. See these two trackers: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-31845 "for backwards compatibility it is necessary to have the 'id' as default instead of newly supported idnumber" http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-28518 "The current implementation of the database enrolment method allows for specification of a course category. This course category must exist in Moodle already and be the category id stored in the course_category table" If 28518 gets resolved and implemented, then there would be the ability to align an external source id via the category id number with an internal category id to create courses in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Missing settings in Collapsed Topics
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Matt, Ok, I think after a few hours investigation that I have a solution where an installation of Collapsed Topics has gone wrong and the capabilities have not been created.  Therefore please try the following procedure (everybody else DO NOT try on a production server until confirmed as ok, and even then after a backup): Put Moodle in maintenance mode. Assuming that CT files are already in place in '/course/format/topcoll'. Remove all 'topcoll' ('format_topcoll' and 'format/topcoll') rows from the following tables in the database: config_plugins, capabilities, role_capabilities and course_format_options. In the 'config' table, find the row for 'allversionshash' ('name' attribute) and set to an empty string, i.e. clear completely. Perform a 'Purge all caches'. Go to 'Site administration -> Notifications'.  The URL should have no 'cache' parameter and if it does, change to 'cache=0' and reload. This should kick start the update checking mechanism and reinstall the format. Put Moodle out of maintenance mode. Note: If you had set any previous CT specific course settings, then these will be lost. Cheers, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: API Access To Create Course
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Gareth. In my case going to create these hundreds of page is a bit time consuming. I figured out a way specific to my use case. I am sharing the summary. In case someone else may find it useful. Procedure To Create a Course ******************************** 1.Insert into mdl_course  with your parameters. Choose ID that would be max(course_id) + 1 2. Insert into mdl_context with following id = max(id) + 1 contextlevel =  50 // that is context lavel for course. you can check lib/accesslib.php instanceid    = course_id // you must have got this in step 1 path              = get path of your category and your id depth           = 3 3. Insert into mdl_course_section // Insert number of sections you are intending to have. 4. insert into mdl_enrol Procedure to Add Pages Repeat following steps number of pages you want to add 1. Insert into mdl_page 2. Insert into mdl_course_module 3. insert into mdl_context 4. Update the sequence field with id grom course_module. The above steps worked for me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Only view one topic when editing a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there any way to, as a teacher, only view one topic of a course when in editing mode? I reuse courses from one year to the next, so there are a LOT of activities in the course. Even thought the course is set to show one topic only, when I enter editing mode, it displays all the topics, which makes the page take quite a while to load, since there are many activities. This means doing simple administrative things on the course (adding assignments, editing multiple assignments, etc.) takes a lot longer since each time it must reload the page, it must load the entire course. It seems this is the standard behavior, but I was hoping someone with more experience than me might have a good solution? (One alternative would be if there is an easy way to copy an entire topic from one course to another. Then I can just copy topics of the course as the year progresses). Thanks so much.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only view one topic when editing a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you thought about using Metacourse 's to break up the course into smaller more manageable chunks?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only view one topic when editing a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: I hadn't thought of metacourses; I'm not too familiar with them. My understanding was they exist to allow multiple courses to share resources. That's not really what I want to do here. I have one course that just happens to already have a year's worth of resources in it, so the course page is very long when all topics are displayed on the same page. Am I misunderstanding metacourses? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only view one topic when editing a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Metacourses allow one course to be 'master' course that you enrol on.  Then you have child courses that can be accessed without further enrolment.  Therefore you can break down a large course into manageable sections .  Each course has its own set of contained activities / resources.  You would need to backup / restore the big course into each of the child courses and remove the activities / resources you know longer need.  Big job. An alternative is a programmatic one such that when editing you have to click on a section to edit them as you want.  However, this means that moving activities / resources between sections is impossible.  This does mean modifying the code.  It would be possible, but how long to work out the changes, difficult to say without a de-risking exercise. Or use Collapsed Topics where all of the activities / resources are still there, just not shown unless you open a toggle.  Therefore easier to D&D from say section 30 to section 1.  Page load probably the same as you currently have. Critically I would start to question why a course has become so big.  Perhaps consider leaving it as is and then progressively transfer to a metacourse solution with a course for each section.

Important: This is still a 'release candidate' because of 'Subsection support' which has been incredibly difficult to support to the extent that I've had to wave a 'white flag' and remove the 'numsections' setting.  The course format API has been broken apart into so many interconnected small pieces (each tending to have separate PHP, JS and Mustache files), https://moodledev.io/docs/4.5/apis/plugintypes/format#format-output-classes-and-templates and https://moodledev.io/docs/4.5/apis/plugintypes/format#the-course-editor-structure , that it is difficult at times to understand and keep in working memory what is going on and where a given element of functionality is implemented to the extent where it can be overridden and changed.  Thus the format will now operate as 'Topics' does in terms of number of sections management.  Collapsed Topics was only ever designed to operate on sections and as such sees sub-sections as different entities not related to the number of sections in a course.  Collapsed Topics will now not allow you to have as many 'Sub sections' as you want - as was in V405.0.2 - due to increased chance of course restore failure, see: MDL-84874 .  Additional tracker issues of interest for this are: MDL-84038 and MDL-84291 . Because of the removal of 'numsections', this has an impact on backup and restore, which I've tested.  However with such a change brings risk and a greater chance of error, thus I cannot stress enough that you MUST test and be sure that the format works as expected before it goes anywhere near a production server .  I found with the Grid format that once 'numsections' was removed that it was tricky to go back, and therefore it would be unlikely even with the flexibility I like of being able to set the number of sections both as a course setting and add / remove in the course itself. I have refactored the whole toggle state preference JavaScript such that it no longer uses YUI.  This I hope will help to keep the format going for many years to come as older technologies are removed from core. Note: Always install on a test server to confirm that the format does what you want it to do before updating or installing on a production server!  And as this release could contain bugs and so I strongly recommend that you check on a test server first!  Not sure how to set one up?  Then look at the 'Installer packages' on https://download.moodle.org/releases/latest/ . Ensure that you have multiple backups of all data before using.  Please report any issues. i.e. 'bugs' with this release ONLY here.  Before doing so please read 'Reporting issues' on the 'Information' tab on the course format 'Settings' under 'Site administration' -> 'Plugins' -> 'Course formats' -> 'Collapsed Topics'. If you find this post useful, then please mark it so. Thank you, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Making a Point Based Course?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello, I'm not sure if this is the correct place to post this, but I'm
trying to create a course that requires 500 points to pass each section. Each
section has activities that are different point values (100, 50, 15...) and a
student gets that amount of points when they pass or complete an activity. The course is completed when all sections have 500 or more
points. I have been looking at points and scales, but neither seem
to be able to do this. It looks like a hack may be to assign a scale to each
activity and if a student gets a passing score, have the scale be the number of
points. But I don't know where to go from there. How do I do this? What documentation should I read? Thank you,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Making a Point Based Course?
ResponsesInList.Text: You could consider is having a gradebook category for each section of content in the course. Then add a Page module (which could simply be text that congratulates the students for completing the section) to the end of each section of content and restrict the page module to be available only once students have earned a certain amount of points for that gradebook section. Then you can set the course completion to be dependent upon the students opening each of the "page modules" that are in the sections.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Making a Point Based Course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Agree with John, generally.  Keep in mind...if you have some activities that have a required score, setting a course grade to pass might undermine that--if there are 500 points and 5 activities where you want 80% or better to pass each activity.  With a required course grade of 400 (80%), a participant could score 50/90/100/100/70 and still 'pass' with 410 points--and that is with two failed activities.  You might want to add activity completion requirements as well that, using John's example, only allow the last thing to display when you reach each requirement. And be clear about the requirement--you must have 80% on each activity AND 80% overall.  Sometimes students try to game the system. Most activities have a grade by default (either one assigned on completion--quiz, scorm , lesson --or one you give manually--forums, glossary or assignments).  You can set restrictions to require specific scores/completion before the next one is done as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Multiple "sections"?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everybody- I'm a Moodle newbie but I am very impressed so far. I'm a firefighter with a large urban fire department, with a large MS Access training records database kept at the fire academy. My current job involves a ton of work just to keep this monster working, and I will move us over to Moodle, with a just little help. We (me and the academy's summer intern - a CS grad student, thankfully) have our basic setup running nicely on a windows box, with phpmyadmin, mrbs , and php acceleration added in. The intent is to begin with Moodle as a central record-keeping tool AND a repository for course presentation materials and handouts. Once it does that convincingly, and with less effort than what we have to do now, we'll expand into all the other features. So far, works GREAT. Our difficulty is this: the academy training right now is recorded in MS Access with three key fields: userid, courseid, and completion_date. The course duration varies from 23 weeks down to single day seminars. The thing to keep in mind is the focus on the completion date - the "finish date" which we use to build each FF's master training record and produce college-type transcripts . (We are also a credit-granting agency with a full-time registrar.) In terms of enrolling students, the six month courses and other "longer" courses work fine in Moodle as is. A student would only enroll in such a course once. The single-day training that we have is repetitive, though, and is scheduled in terms of firefighting units , not individual members/students. We know Engine 1 is coming for the drill, as scheduled, but the members working that day will be enrolled/recorded as trained only after they get here. A firefighter may come four times in a year for the same drill - "Tactical Unconscious FF Removal" or "Self-Rescue Rope Refresher." Upon completion of the drill, a hand-written sign-in sheet goes to the data-entry person. Most firefighters and their officers will repeat at least one of the single-day drills during a two-year period. They are essentially re-taking a one-day class. We've looked at groups , restoring courses, etc. and haven't found a solution yet. (One particular drill/class is conducted 300 days a year, and most training is conducted at least once a month.) The solution we desire will let the data-entry person, who is swamped, enroll anyone off of her backlog pile, some of it more than a month old, as well as the current 'today' students. It will let specialty instructors build attendee lists for future multi-week classes that are offerred 4x a year. And, eventually, regular instructors in the classroom will sign in to Moodle and before starting their refresher training Powerpoints or printing their new handouts, they can go around the room and take names/enroll students right from the podium. In short, we need to enroll students in a course, then find and enroll them again in a new "section" of the same course next week or next month, and we need to back-fill 200,000+ training records across 20,000+ active/retired members within 400+ current/archive courses. We've been tempted to add a training_date to the role_ assignment table, then modify the assign.php/html files so when assigning the role 'student' for a course, the user will have to pick a 'section_complete_date.' (the date of training for one-day courses, and the "finish date" for multi-day or multi-week training.) As we say over the radio, "Can anyone advise...?"

ResponsesInList.Text: It sounds like you want to use Moodle to track attendance to an Instructor Led Training class where the Instructor will use moodle but the students will not, is that correct?

ResponsesInList.Text: Correct - initially the instructors will be the only users. The goal is to get the full usefulness out of Moodle eventually. Like many other things, there is an incremental process here, trying to show the usefulness of this technology to some people who are aggressively non-technical (about computers, that is. I work with chiefs who could strip apart a hydraulic Hurst tool behind their back.) We are beginning to refocus on the attendance mod. Posted this today in regards: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=101711#p449219

ResponsesInList.Title: Any course Format for courses with regular dates?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am using moodle 2.5.1 with buckle. I am a teacher and want to use moodle for my courses. (In fact we want to use moodle schoolwide with me as administrator.) Now as usual in schools my courses always take place at the same time of the week. Let's say tuesdays and fridays. Now I would like to have a format that automatically creates a section for each of these occurances with the corresponding date as it's name. To me it seems obvious to use such a structure, so I cannot believe noone has ever done something like that. So any suggestions how I can achieve that behaviour? Thanks in advance Michael

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Any course Format for courses with regular dates?
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Michael, There are some temporal based formats out there including Weeks, Collapsed Topics (with Weekly and Days for sections and in forthcoming order), Weekly format reversed and the Daily format. When you say 'creates a section' do you mean actually create it or unhide it from the students?  As when I was teaching I wanted to prepare as much as possible and then only make it available when I wanted it to be so.  Also, I preferred semi-manually as often I would repeat lessons over different days and being ICT other things like Citizenship / events / exams etc. would break the sequence for one particular class so having an automated system would have made this tricky.  I tended to stick with having a reversed weekly format as ICT was only taught for one lesson per week at KS3. Cheers, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: same course with two different names
ResponsesInList.Text: No, not directly, and not with a straight out of the box Moodle. You could have 1 "content" course, and 2 "access" courses, and use something like Sub-course to turn the content course into an activity in the "access" courses. Otherwise you're looking at something closer to a repository model, where all your "course content" is held in a repository system, and then linked to 2 different Moodle courses. This however potentially changes in the future as more "content" can be stored in the Moodle Content Bank, but (I think) at the moment that is mostly just H5P content.
